subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Here s my main objection in a nutshell: - Kingsley spells path with #32 Ah and as with #30 At - Most Americans spell both path and as with #30 At If we
messageBody:
Here's my main objection in a nutshell:

- Kingsley spells "path" with #32 Ah and "as" with #30 At

- Most Americans spell both "path" and "as" with #30 At

If we must all now use #32 for the word "path" while still using
#30 for "as" it would be problem enough. But worse is that
most Americans could never use QS correctly as they would never know
where to put other words with the "apple" sound ( sampa /{/ ). One
could try to write a Byzantine rule to help but it would never work
because as John Cowan wrote earlier "...If you can't hear the
difference, you're going to make mistakes...". And the result of these
inevitable errors will be more illegible than QS written in dialect
ever would.

Now if we let Americans use #30 for the word "path" then we must
let Tasmanians use #28 if they want. I have observed that this creates
no difficulties in practice and we will still all be able to read
their towering body of literature without difficulty.



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> John Cowan wrote:
>
>
>
> >
> > > - It freezes QS spelling so changes in pronunciation will never be
> > > reflected in writing. One is just creating a new TO with
letters of a
> > > different shape which is a pointless exercise.
> >
> > Not at all. A huge number of old mergers (meet/meat, vain/vein) are
> > disposed of, as well as gobs of pointless irregularities that have
never
> > meant anything to anybody.
> >
>
> To be fair, Anthony made (or implied) 2 points:
>
> (1) He believes you are a advocating a writing system very similar to
> TO. That is, you want a standardized (or somewhat standardized?) way of
> spelling words. (I am inferring this from another post.) You also want
> the writing system to be phonemical, not phonetical. You want the
system
> to be written in a standardized way that ignores dialect, so that
> someone from America could read someone's writing from Australia and
> understand it easily, unlike when someone from America heard someone
> from Australia.
>
> (2) He thinks such a new system would be "pointless exercise."
>
> You addressed (2), but only addressed (1) implicitly. I am only
pointing
> this out so that because many on this mailing list seem to be dead set
> against how you would have QS used. I am not saying I agree or disagree
> (I still have to weigh the whole matter); I just want clarity on this
> issue so later no one is surprised.
>
> Paul
>
